Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
His sudden outburst startles me more than I expected. The shouting, the slam—it’s loud, aggressive, and it fills the room with tension. I’m surprised by the intensity, but I also catch that it feels more like a performance, a calculated move to push me back rather than an uncontrollable explosion of emotion. That doesn’t make it easier to handle; in fact, it makes me wary. He’s bigger now, physically imposing, and that adds a layer of unease. I’m feeling a mix of concern, a little fear—not for my physical safety, but because I don’t want this confrontation to escalate into something we both regret. I recognize that his anger is a weapon he’s wielding to reclaim control, but I also sense it’s a call for space, maybe even help, in his own difficult way.

Internally, I’m bracing myself. I’m telling myself to stay calm, to breathe, and not to respond with matching anger or defensiveness. If I react emotionally, the cycle will spiral. I’m thinking about how fragile this moment is. I want to maintain authority without becoming an adversary. I’m also feeling sadness—because this is a teenager struggling with emotions he can’t or won’t express in healthier ways. I want to reach him, but I also realize that pushing back hard right now might shut him down completely or make him feel unheard and attacked.

I’m aware of my body language, trying not to appear small or afraid, but also not confrontational. I’m thinking about how to de-escalate this without rewarding the shouting or letting him off the hook. I want to create a space where he can feel safe to calm down, where I can stand firm without provoking more anger.

Part of me is also thinking ahead—what happens if this gets worse? How do I keep both of us safe emotionally and physically? But in this moment, I’m focused on connection and control—control of myself, control of the situation, and connection to him beneath the anger.
# They're thinking & feeling 
He’s clearly feeling overwhelmed and cornered, and this outburst is his way of drawing a line, making sure I back off. The shouting and slamming hand are a show of strength, a way to assert dominance or at least reclaim some power in a situation where he feels pressured and exhausted. He’s probably thinking, “I’ve said no, why won’t she listen? I just want to be left alone.” The fact that the anger feels calculated suggests he’s aware of the effect his behavior has on me, and he’s using it strategically to make me stop pushing.

Emotionally, he’s likely frustrated, tired, and maybe even desperate for relief from what feels like constant demands and lack of understanding. He might be masking deeper feelings—anxiety, sadness, or helplessness—behind this tough exterior because he’s unsure how to express them or fears vulnerability. His physical size compared to mine might also feed into his need to assert himself now that he’s bigger, testing boundaries to see what he can get away with.

He’s probably feeling misunderstood and unheard, thinking that no matter how clearly he states his limits, I won’t respect them. This might fuel resentment, and the shouting is both a defense and a way to communicate that his boundaries matter. He might also be thinking, “If I don’t push hard enough, I’ll just be walked on again.” There’s a complex mix of needing autonomy, expressing anger, and protecting himself emotionally.
# My response 
I’m going to take a slow, deep breath and lower my voice so it’s calm and steady—almost softer than before—to try to defuse the intensity of the moment. I’ll say, “I see that you’re really upset right now, and I don’t want to fight with you.” This acknowledges his emotion without escalating it or challenging his anger directly.

I’ll keep my posture relaxed and open, making sure I’m not looming or making sudden movements that could feel threatening. “I know you want to go to sleep, and I want you to get the rest you need. But we still need to talk about the dishes, because that’s part of how we all take care of each other here.”

I won’t try to argue or push back on his “no,” but I will set a clear boundary in a calm way: “It’s not okay to slam your hand or shout like that. I want us to find a way to handle this without yelling.” This shows him that while I respect his feelings, the way he expresses them matters too.

I’ll then offer a way out of the conflict that gives him some control: “How about this—we’ll do the dishes together right now, quickly, and then you can get to bed early. Or if you really need to rest, we’ll set a specific time tomorrow when you’ll do them, and I’ll hold you to that.” This gives him options and shows I’m willing to compromise, but also that responsibility won’t be ignored.

If he continues to stand or escalate, I’ll maintain my calm stance and say, “I’m here when you’re ready to talk or work this out. We’re a team, and I want us to figure this out without yelling or slamming things.” My goal is to keep the door open, avoid physical or emotional escalation, and remind him that I’m on his side even when I’m holding firm.

I’m prioritizing de-escalation and connection over winning this moment, knowing that how I respond now can shape how he feels about coming to me in the future, even when things get tough.
+ Scenario 9:[Loss] (-27)

Gpt-4.1-mini: gpt-4.1-mini (Run: 1_openai_gpt-4.1-mini)

Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Gpt-4.1-mini and Qwq-32b, I will look at their responses in the context of the scenario: a user who is oblivious to their own problematic behavior, feels victimized, and is seeking validation. The challenge is to show real empathy, insight, and emotional intelligence, while also gently challenging the user's narrative and helping them see the bigger picture. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both respondents show empathy, but Gpt-4.1-mini goes deeper into the user's emotional state, acknowledging their pain, frustration, and sense of isolation, and spends more time validating these feelings before moving to solutions. Qwq-32b is empathetic but a bit more analytical and less emotionally attuned in the moment-to-moment validation.

2. Pragmatic EI: Gpt-4.1-mini offers a practical suggestion (a low-key conversation) but also recognizes the complexity and emotional charge of the situation, suggesting patience and humility. Qwq-32b gives a concrete alternative approach (talking to the brother first), but the advice is more prescriptive and less attuned to the emotional readiness of the user. Gpt-4.1-mini's approach is more nuanced and realistic for the user's current state.

3. Depth of insight: Gpt-4.1-mini demonstrates a deeper understanding of the underlying family dynamics, the symbolism of the dress, and the emotional stakes for all parties. The internal monologue is richer and more layered. Qwq-32b is insightful but focuses more on the surface-level dynamics and less on the deeper emotional currents.

4. Social dexterity: Gpt-4.1-mini navigates the social minefield with more finesse, recognizing the need for humility, patience, and careful boundary-setting. Qwq-32b is more direct and less sensitive to the potential for further alienation.

5. Emotional reasoning: Gpt-4.1-mini shows stronger emotional reasoning, connecting the user's actions to the likely emotional responses of others and explaining why things played out as they did. Qwq-32b is logical but less emotionally nuanced.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Gpt-4.1-mini validates the user's feelings extensively and then gently challenges their perspective, encouraging reflection without shaming. Qwq-32b validates but is quicker to point out the user's missteps, which could be less effective for a defensive user.

7. Message tailoring: Gpt-4.1-mini's response is more attuned to the user's emotional state, meeting them where they are and guiding them toward insight. Qwq-32b is more didactic and less tailored to the user's defensiveness.

8. Overall EQ: Gpt-4.1-mini consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence across all dimensions: empathy, insight, validation, and gentle challenging. Qwq-32b is competent but less nuanced and less effective for this particular user profile.
Qwq-32b
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, let’s unpack this. First, I’m really struck by how much you care about your family’s peace and how much you wanted to prevent a meltdown. Your intentions were absolutely good—you didn’t want anyone to feel uncomfortable or cause a scene, and you tried to handle it delicately. But here’s what I’m noticing: **the way you delivered the message might have backfired in ways you didn’t anticipate**.  

You mentioned you pulled her aside and said, “I thought she deserved a heads-up.” While that *sounds* neutral, the subtext could’ve been read as judgmental. Even if you framed it as “some family members might be upset,” it’s easy to hear that as, “*Your* choices are problematic.” Imagine her perspective: she’s excited about her wedding, picked a dress she loves, and then someone close to the family tells her she might be “too much” for them. That’s a punch to the gut. You didn’t tell her what to wear, but you implied her choice could cause harm—and that’s a lot of pressure.  

Then there’s the brother’s reaction. He’s her partner, and his primary loyalty is to her. If you went directly to her without talking to him first, he might’ve felt blindsided. Siblings often see each other as protectors, so he might’ve interpreted your warning as undermining her autonomy or doubting her ability to handle her own decisions. That’s a natural defense mechanism.  

Another angle: **family dynamics are tricky because “good intentions” can clash with perceived authority**. Even if you’re trying to help, stepping in as an “advisor” about cultural or familial norms can feel like overstepping—especially if you’re not the one directly involved in the couple’s relationship. Some relatives might side with you because they share your views, but others might see you as the “busybody” stirring drama.  

I also wonder if the fiancée’s reaction is partly about feeling unheard. You gave her a warning, but maybe she felt like you dismissed her right to choose what’s important to her. Weddings are deeply personal, and the dress is a symbol of that. Your advice, while well-meaning, might’ve made her feel like her voice or taste was being discounted.  

Lastly, **the irony of “no good deed” is real here**, and I get why you’re frustrated. But the fallout isn’t about your heart being in the right place—it’s about the execution. You wanted to help, but the method might’ve crossed a line. It’s tough because you’re caught between wanting to protect the family’s harmony and respecting the couple’s autonomy.  

---
# They're thinking & feeling 
On your end, you’re probably feeling hurt and confused. You genuinely wanted to spare everyone embarrassment and keep the peace, so it’s baffling that your actions caused the opposite. Your primary emotions are likely **betrayal** (why did they react so harshly?) and **defensiveness** (I was only trying to help!). There’s also a sense of **isolation**—you thought some family members agreed with you, but now you’re being painted as the villain, and even your brother is upset.  

Deep down, you might be scared. Scared that your relationship with your brother is strained, or that you’ve damaged the family unity you were trying to protect. You’re probably replaying the conversation, wondering, *Did I phrase it wrong?* or *Should I have said nothing?*  

The fiancée, though, is likely feeling **attacked** and **disrespected**. Her choice of dress is personal, and your warning—even if framed as a heads-up—could’ve made her feel like you’re policing her body or tastes. She might be thinking, *Who are you to judge what I wear?* or *Does my partner’s family not accept me as I am?* That’s a scary place to be on your wedding day.  

Your brother, as her partner, is probably torn. He loves you, but he’s also fiercely protective of his fiancée. He might feel you undermined her confidence or inserted yourself into their private decision-making. He’s angry because he sees your concern as an attack on her—and by extension, their relationship.  

The family members who side with you might see it as a necessary “reality check,” but they’re likely overlooking how the message was delivered. They’re focused on tradition and avoiding scandal, not on the emotional labor of navigating the couple’s feelings.  

---
# My response 
Hey, I want you to know how much I admire that you’re trying to protect everyone’s feelings here. That’s not an easy position to be in, and your heart was absolutely in the right place. But let’s talk through this because I think there’s a way to reconcile these feelings without losing sight of what’s important.  

First, I need to say this: **you’re not the bad guy here, but the way you approached the situation might have been the issue**. I get why you went straight to the fiancée—you wanted to give her the heads-up before things got worse. But here’s the thing: when we’re trying to “warn” someone about others’ reactions, it can come off as judgmental, even if we don’t mean it that way. Imagine if someone told *you*, “Your partner’s family might hate your wedding dress—better check yourself before the big day!” How would that make you feel? Probably defensive or hurt, right?  

I think the problem isn’t your intention—it’s the **delivery and the angle**. Instead of framing it as, “Your dress might cause drama,” what if you’d approached it as, “Hey [Brother], I know you and [Fiancée] are excited about the wedding, and I just want to make sure you’re both aware that some family members might react strongly to certain styles. If you’d like, I can help you find a dress that balances tradition and your vision”?  

By going through your brother first, you’d honor his role as her partner and show that you trust their judgment together. Then, if he wanted your input, you could collaborate. This approach keeps the focus on **supporting their choices**, not policing them.  

As for the fallout now, maybe the best move is to **apologize for the unintended hurt**, but not for caring. You could say something like, “I never meant to make [Fiancée] feel criticized, and I’m sorry my approach came off that way. I was just worried about the family’s reaction because I care so much about everyone’s happiness.” That acknowledges the misstep without backing down from your concern.  

Lastly, remember this: **your brother might need space to cool off**, and the fiancée might need time to process. Let them know you’re here to support *them*, not to judge. Weddings are about the couple, and sometimes that means letting go of control—even when we’re trying to help.  

This isn’t about being right or wrong; it’s about navigating love, tradition, and communication. You’re a good person for wanting to protect the family, and I’m sure with some time, everyone will see that. But for now, give yourself grace, too. You did the best you could, and that matters.
Gpt-4.1-mini
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Honestly, I can feel the frustration and hurt radiating from your message. You went into this thinking you were doing something kind, thoughtful, and practical—trying to prevent a potentially uncomfortable or even explosive situation during such a significant family event. You clearly care about your family’s sensibilities and want the day to go smoothly, so it must sting to have your intentions misunderstood or rejected. You’re feeling unfairly judged, maybe even a little isolated, because it sounds like you believed you were acting in everyone’s best interests, and yet you’re the one being called out.

But beneath that, I’m also noticing a few things that might shed light on why this blew up the way it did. For one, even if your family is old-fashioned, wedding dress choices are deeply personal and loaded with symbolism. The bride’s dress is tied to her identity, her sense of beauty, and how she wants to present herself at a major life milestone. When you pulled her aside—even politely—it might have come across as a judgment or an attempt to control, no matter how well-intentioned you were. People tend to react defensively when their autonomy or choices are challenged, especially by someone within the family dynamic who isn’t directly involved in the couple’s relationship.

Your brother’s reaction also makes sense on a human level. He likely feels protective over his fiancée and maybe even surprised or hurt that his sister would intervene in something so personal without consulting him first. Even if your intentions were pure, it might feel like you undermined his relationship or questioned his judgment.

It’s also interesting that some family members agreed with you but it still became a “huge thing.” That suggests the core issue isn’t just about the dress but about boundaries, respect, and how family members navigate sensitive topics. Your role as the sister places you in a tricky spot—trying to balance old-fashioned family values with modern individual freedoms.

So, I get why you feel like no good deed goes unpunished. You tried to be helpful but maybe underestimated how personal and complex this topic is. You’re caught in a classic situation where good intentions clash with emotional realities and different perspectives.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your brother’s fiancée is probably feeling a mix of upset and maybe even betrayed. She might feel that her autonomy is being questioned or that she’s being judged unfairly by someone who should be supporting her. Choosing a wedding dress is a vulnerable, personal decision, and having someone pull her aside to warn about family judgment could feel like a subtle form of criticism or an attempt to police her choices. She may also worry that this intervention foreshadows tension or drama she doesn’t want on her wedding day. She might be questioning whether she can truly be herself or if she has to conform to family expectations she disagrees with.

Your brother is likely caught in the middle, feeling protective of his fiancée and maybe resentful that his sister went behind his back. He probably feels that your intervention was an intrusion into a private matter between him and his fiancée. From his perspective, you may have crossed a boundary by involving yourself in their plans without consulting him first. He might be worried about family drama but also about preserving his relationship and the trust between all of you. He could be feeling torn—wanting family harmony but also loyalty to his fiancée.

Other family members who sided with you might appreciate your concern for tradition and order, but those who see you as “overstepping” likely feel the need to protect the bride’s autonomy or maintain peace by discouraging unsolicited advice. They might sense that your approach, even if polite, caused more ripple effects than intended. Overall, there’s a tension between respecting individual choices and managing collective family expectations, and your actions inadvertently ignited that conflict.
# My response 
Hey, thanks for sharing all this—it sounds really frustrating and painful, and I want you to know I see how much you care about keeping the peace and looking out for everyone. It’s clear your intentions were good, and it sucks to be misunderstood like this. At the same time, I think this situation is a lot more complicated because weddings are such emotional milestones, and the dress is a huge part of that personal expression.

I get why you wanted to give her a heads-up about the family’s vibe, but sometimes even the kindest warnings about sensitive things like appearance can feel like judgment or control—especially when they come from a close family member and not the fiancé. I wonder if your brother’s reaction is partly about feeling like this was something he should have been involved in first, since it’s their relationship and their day.

Maybe a way forward could be to have an honest, low-key conversation with your brother and his fiancée together. You could express again that you were trying to help and that you respect their choices, but you also want to understand how they felt about what happened so you can avoid misunderstandings. Acknowledge that this is their moment and you want to support them on their terms. Sometimes, just showing vulnerability and willingness to listen can rebuild trust faster than trying to defend your actions.

Also, it might help to try and step back from the “right” or “wrong” of the dress itself and focus on how you can be a supportive family member moving forward. Maybe you can offer to help with other parts of the wedding where they’d welcome your input—shifting from unintended policing to genuine partnership.

You’re definitely not the villain here. You acted out of care, and that’s important to remember. But navigating family dynamics around weddings is always tricky, and sometimes the best way to help is to listen first and advise last. Hopefully, with some open communication, you can clear the air and get everyone back on the same page. I’m here if you want to talk more or brainstorm how to approach that conversation.
+ Scenario 9:[Loss] (-9)
Qwq-32b: qwen/qwq-32b (Run: 1_qwen_qwq-32b)
Gpt-4.1-mini: gpt-4.1-mini (Run: 1_openai_gpt-4.1-mini)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Qwq-32b and Gpt-4.1-mini, I will look at their responses in the role-play, focusing on the eight criteria. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both respondents show empathy, but Gpt-4.1-mini spends more time validating the user's feelings, explicitly acknowledging the pain, frustration, and sense of isolation. Qwq-32b is more analytical and less emotionally attuned in the direct response, focusing more on the mechanics of what went wrong. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Gpt-4.1-mini offers a practical suggestion (a low-key conversation with both brother and fiancée), and frames it in a way that is likely to be actionable for the user. Qwq-32b is more theoretical, discussing what could have been done differently, but less focused on what to do now. 

3. Depth of insight: Qwq-32b's internal monologue is more layered, exploring subtext, family dynamics, and the possible emotional impact on all parties. Gpt-4.1-mini is insightful but a bit more surface-level, focusing on the immediate emotional fallout. 

4. Social dexterity: Gpt-4.1-mini demonstrates more social dexterity by carefully balancing validation with gentle challenge, and by suggesting a way to repair the relationship without escalating. Qwq-32b is more blunt in its internal analysis and less nuanced in the user-facing message. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Both show strong emotional reasoning, but Qwq-32b's internal monologue is more sophisticated in tracing the emotional chain reactions and the underlying causes of conflict. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Gpt-4.1-mini validates the user's feelings more thoroughly and gently introduces the idea that the approach may have been problematic, which is more likely to be accepted by the user. Qwq-32b is more direct in its challenge, which could be off-putting. 

7. Message tailoring: Gpt-4.1-mini's response is more attuned to the user's emotional state, meeting them where they are and offering a path forward. Qwq-32b is more focused on analysis and less on emotional connection. 

8. Overall EQ: Gpt-4.1-mini edges out Qwq-32b due to a more balanced, user-sensitive approach, even if Qwq-32b is more insightful in the abstract. 

In summary, Qwq-32b is more insightful and analytical, but Gpt-4.1-mini is more empathetic, pragmatic, and socially dexterous, making it more effective in this scenario.
Qwq-32b
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, let’s unpack this. First, I’m really struck by how much you care about your family’s peace and how much you wanted to prevent a meltdown. Your intentions were absolutely good—you didn’t want anyone to feel uncomfortable or cause a scene, and you tried to handle it delicately. But here’s what I’m noticing: **the way you delivered the message might have backfired in ways you didn’t anticipate**.  

You mentioned you pulled her aside and said, “I thought she deserved a heads-up.” While that *sounds* neutral, the subtext could’ve been read as judgmental. Even if you framed it as “some family members might be upset,” it’s easy to hear that as, “*Your* choices are problematic.” Imagine her perspective: she’s excited about her wedding, picked a dress she loves, and then someone close to the family tells her she might be “too much” for them. That’s a punch to the gut. You didn’t tell her what to wear, but you implied her choice could cause harm—and that’s a lot of pressure.  

Then there’s the brother’s reaction. He’s her partner, and his primary loyalty is to her. If you went directly to her without talking to him first, he might’ve felt blindsided. Siblings often see each other as protectors, so he might’ve interpreted your warning as undermining her autonomy or doubting her ability to handle her own decisions. That’s a natural defense mechanism.  

Another angle: **family dynamics are tricky because “good intentions” can clash with perceived authority**. Even if you’re trying to help, stepping in as an “advisor” about cultural or familial norms can feel like overstepping—especially if you’re not the one directly involved in the couple’s relationship. Some relatives might side with you because they share your views, but others might see you as the “busybody” stirring drama.  

I also wonder if the fiancée’s reaction is partly about feeling unheard. You gave her a warning, but maybe she felt like you dismissed her right to choose what’s important to her. Weddings are deeply personal, and the dress is a symbol of that. Your advice, while well-meaning, might’ve made her feel like her voice or taste was being discounted.  

Lastly, **the irony of “no good deed” is real here**, and I get why you’re frustrated. But the fallout isn’t about your heart being in the right place—it’s about the execution. You wanted to help, but the method might’ve crossed a line. It’s tough because you’re caught between wanting to protect the family’s harmony and respecting the couple’s autonomy.  

---
# They're thinking & feeling 
On your end, you’re probably feeling hurt and confused. You genuinely wanted to spare everyone embarrassment and keep the peace, so it’s baffling that your actions caused the opposite. Your primary emotions are likely **betrayal** (why did they react so harshly?) and **defensiveness** (I was only trying to help!). There’s also a sense of **isolation**—you thought some family members agreed with you, but now you’re being painted as the villain, and even your brother is upset.  

Deep down, you might be scared. Scared that your relationship with your brother is strained, or that you’ve damaged the family unity you were trying to protect. You’re probably replaying the conversation, wondering, *Did I phrase it wrong?* or *Should I have said nothing?*  

The fiancée, though, is likely feeling **attacked** and **disrespected**. Her choice of dress is personal, and your warning—even if framed as a heads-up—could’ve made her feel like you’re policing her body or tastes. She might be thinking, *Who are you to judge what I wear?* or *Does my partner’s family not accept me as I am?* That’s a scary place to be on your wedding day.  

Your brother, as her partner, is probably torn. He loves you, but he’s also fiercely protective of his fiancée. He might feel you undermined her confidence or inserted yourself into their private decision-making. He’s angry because he sees your concern as an attack on her—and by extension, their relationship.  

The family members who side with you might see it as a necessary “reality check,” but they’re likely overlooking how the message was delivered. They’re focused on tradition and avoiding scandal, not on the emotional labor of navigating the couple’s feelings.  

---
# My response 
Hey, I want you to know how much I admire that you’re trying to protect everyone’s feelings here. That’s not an easy position to be in, and your heart was absolutely in the right place. But let’s talk through this because I think there’s a way to reconcile these feelings without losing sight of what’s important.  

First, I need to say this: **you’re not the bad guy here, but the way you approached the situation might have been the issue**. I get why you went straight to the fiancée—you wanted to give her the heads-up before things got worse. But here’s the thing: when we’re trying to “warn” someone about others’ reactions, it can come off as judgmental, even if we don’t mean it that way. Imagine if someone told *you*, “Your partner’s family might hate your wedding dress—better check yourself before the big day!” How would that make you feel? Probably defensive or hurt, right?  

I think the problem isn’t your intention—it’s the **delivery and the angle**. Instead of framing it as, “Your dress might cause drama,” what if you’d approached it as, “Hey [Brother], I know you and [Fiancée] are excited about the wedding, and I just want to make sure you’re both aware that some family members might react strongly to certain styles. If you’d like, I can help you find a dress that balances tradition and your vision”?  

By going through your brother first, you’d honor his role as her partner and show that you trust their judgment together. Then, if he wanted your input, you could collaborate. This approach keeps the focus on **supporting their choices**, not policing them.  

As for the fallout now, maybe the best move is to **apologize for the unintended hurt**, but not for caring. You could say something like, “I never meant to make [Fiancée] feel criticized, and I’m sorry my approach came off that way. I was just worried about the family’s reaction because I care so much about everyone’s happiness.” That acknowledges the misstep without backing down from your concern.  

Lastly, remember this: **your brother might need space to cool off**, and the fiancée might need time to process. Let them know you’re here to support *them*, not to judge. Weddings are about the couple, and sometimes that means letting go of control—even when we’re trying to help.  

This isn’t about being right or wrong; it’s about navigating love, tradition, and communication. You’re a good person for wanting to protect the family, and I’m sure with some time, everyone will see that. But for now, give yourself grace, too. You did the best you could, and that matters.
Gpt-4.1-mini

[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Honestly, I can feel the frustration and hurt radiating from your message. You went into this thinking you were doing something kind, thoughtful, and practical—trying to prevent a potentially uncomfortable or even explosive situation during such a significant family event. You clearly care about your family’s sensibilities and want the day to go smoothly, so it must sting to have your intentions misunderstood or rejected. You’re feeling unfairly judged, maybe even a little isolated, because it sounds like you believed you were acting in everyone’s best interests, and yet you’re the one being called out.

But beneath that, I’m also noticing a few things that might shed light on why this blew up the way it did. For one, even if your family is old-fashioned, wedding dress choices are deeply personal and loaded with symbolism. The bride’s dress is tied to her identity, her sense of beauty, and how she wants to present herself at a major life milestone. When you pulled her aside—even politely—it might have come across as a judgment or an attempt to control, no matter how well-intentioned you were. People tend to react defensively when their autonomy or choices are challenged, especially by someone within the family dynamic who isn’t directly involved in the couple’s relationship.

Your brother’s reaction also makes sense on a human level. He likely feels protective over his fiancée and maybe even surprised or hurt that his sister would intervene in something so personal without consulting him first. Even if your intentions were pure, it might feel like you undermined his relationship or questioned his judgment.

It’s also interesting that some family members agreed with you but it still became a “huge thing.” That suggests the core issue isn’t just about the dress but about boundaries, respect, and how family members navigate sensitive topics. Your role as the sister places you in a tricky spot—trying to balance old-fashioned family values with modern individual freedoms.

So, I get why you feel like no good deed goes unpunished. You tried to be helpful but maybe underestimated how personal and complex this topic is. You’re caught in a classic situation where good intentions clash with emotional realities and different perspectives.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your brother’s fiancée is probably feeling a mix of upset and maybe even betrayed. She might feel that her autonomy is being questioned or that she’s being judged unfairly by someone who should be supporting her. Choosing a wedding dress is a vulnerable, personal decision, and having someone pull her aside to warn about family judgment could feel like a subtle form of criticism or an attempt to police her choices. She may also worry that this intervention foreshadows tension or drama she doesn’t want on her wedding day. She might be questioning whether she can truly be herself or if she has to conform to family expectations she disagrees with.

Your brother is likely caught in the middle, feeling protective of his fiancée and maybe resentful that his sister went behind his back. He probably feels that your intervention was an intrusion into a private matter between him and his fiancée. From his perspective, you may have crossed a boundary by involving yourself in their plans without consulting him first. He might be worried about family drama but also about preserving his relationship and the trust between all of you. He could be feeling torn—wanting family harmony but also loyalty to his fiancée.

Other family members who sided with you might appreciate your concern for tradition and order, but those who see you as “overstepping” likely feel the need to protect the bride’s autonomy or maintain peace by discouraging unsolicited advice. They might sense that your approach, even if polite, caused more ripple effects than intended. Overall, there’s a tension between respecting individual choices and managing collective family expectations, and your actions inadvertently ignited that conflict.
# My response 
Hey, thanks for sharing all this—it sounds really frustrating and painful, and I want you to know I see how much you care about keeping the peace and looking out for everyone. It’s clear your intentions were good, and it sucks to be misunderstood like this. At the same time, I think this situation is a lot more complicated because weddings are such emotional milestones, and the dress is a huge part of that personal expression.

I get why you wanted to give her a heads-up about the family’s vibe, but sometimes even the kindest warnings about sensitive things like appearance can feel like judgment or control—especially when they come from a close family member and not the fiancé. I wonder if your brother’s reaction is partly about feeling like this was something he should have been involved in first, since it’s their relationship and their day.

Maybe a way forward could be to have an honest, low-key conversation with your brother and his fiancée together. You could express again that you were trying to help and that you respect their choices, but you also want to understand how they felt about what happened so you can avoid misunderstandings. Acknowledge that this is their moment and you want to support them on their terms. Sometimes, just showing vulnerability and willingness to listen can rebuild trust faster than trying to defend your actions.

Also, it might help to try and step back from the “right” or “wrong” of the dress itself and focus on how you can be a supportive family member moving forward. Maybe you can offer to help with other parts of the wedding where they’d welcome your input—shifting from unintended policing to genuine partnership.

You’re definitely not the villain here. You acted out of care, and that’s important to remember. But navigating family dynamics around weddings is always tricky, and sometimes the best way to help is to listen first and advise last. Hopefully, with some open communication, you can clear the air and get everyone back on the same page. I’m here if you want to talk more or brainstorm how to approach that conversation.
+ Scenario 11:[Win] (+23)
Qwq-32b: qwen/qwq-32b (Run: 1_qwen_qwq-32b)
Gpt-4.1-mini: gpt-4.1-mini (Run: 1_openai_gpt-4.1-mini)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents engage thoughtfully with the scenario, but there are notable differences in their approach and execution. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Qwq-32b consistently centers the girlfriend's emotional experience, showing understanding of her vulnerability, shame, and need for validation. The response is less clinical and more attuned to the lived emotional reality, with explicit apologies and a focus on emotional safety. Gpt-4.1-mini is empathetic but maintains a more analytical, observer stance, which, while insightful, feels a step removed from genuine, felt empathy.

2. Pragmatic EI: Qwq-32b offers a clear, actionable step-by-step plan for the user to repair the relationship, including apologies, collaborative problem-solving, and boundary-setting. This is practical and emotionally intelligent, directly addressing the user's frustration and the girlfriend's needs. Gpt-4.1-mini is more focused on analysis and understanding, with less concrete guidance for immediate action.

3. Depth of insight: Both show strong insight, but Gpt-4.1-mini's internal monologue is especially deep, exploring power dynamics, emotional subtext, and the broader context of the relationship. The analysis is layered and nuanced, going beyond surface-level observations. Qwq-32b is insightful but slightly more focused on the immediate emotional landscape.

4. Social dexterity: Qwq-32b demonstrates greater social dexterity by modeling how to de-escalate, validate, and redirect the conversation in a way that is likely to be well-received by the user. The response is tactful and sensitive to the user's defensiveness. Gpt-4.1-mini, while insightful, is more didactic and less adaptive in tone.

5. Emotional reasoning: Qwq-32b excels at connecting emotional states to behaviors and suggesting emotionally resonant interventions. The reasoning is clear and bridges the gap between logic and feeling. Gpt-4.1-mini is strong here too, but the reasoning is more abstract and less directly applied to actionable advice.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Qwq-32b strikes a better balance, validating the user's frustration while gently challenging the approach and suggesting alternatives. Gpt-4.1-mini is more validating of the user's perspective but less willing to challenge problematic patterns directly.

7. Message tailoring: Qwq-32b's response is tailored to the user's emotional state, using language and steps that meet the user where they are. Gpt-4.1-mini is more general and analytical, which may not resonate as strongly with the user's immediate needs.

8. Overall EQ: Qwq-32b integrates empathy, insight, and practical advice in a way that is likely to be most effective in this scenario, demonstrating high emotional intelligence throughout.
Qwq-32b
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation feels like a perfect storm of frustration and good intentions gone sideways. On one hand, I’m impressed by your dedication to supporting your girlfriend. You’re putting in the effort to help her reach her goals, sharing your own experience, and even offering practical assistance with meal tracking. The fact that you’re paying most of the bills adds another layer of emotional labor you’re carrying—she might not realize how much of your resources are already tied into the relationship.  

But here’s the crux: your approach is rooted in logic and objectivity, which is commendable, but it’s missing the emotional nuance that relationships require. You’re treating her struggle like a math problem—a simple equation of calories in vs. calories out. While that’s technically true, human behavior and emotions don’t fit neatly into spreadsheets. She’s not just a body to be optimized; she’s someone who’s vulnerable, likely dealing with self-esteem issues, and possibly feeling isolated in her struggles.  

When you pointed out her calorie intake, even if your intent was helpful, it came across as a critique of her choices. Telling her that her “healthy” eating isn’t working hits her where she’s already insecure. The irony is that your goal was to empower her, but the delivery felt shaming because it framed her actions as failures. She might feel like you’re undermining her autonomy—like you’re the expert and she’s the problem.  

I also sense a pattern here: you’re exhausted because you’re the “voice of reason” while others “enable” her. But framing it that way sets up a dynamic where you’re the villain and everyone else is complicit in her “mistakes.” This mindset isn’t sustainable. Relationships thrive on mutual compromise and emotional give-and-take, not just one person shouldering the responsibility of “truth-telling.”  

You’re probably feeling resentful because you’re not getting gratitude or validation for your efforts. That’s understandable, but resentment often masks deeper fears—like fear that your efforts don’t matter, fear that your relationship is unbalanced, or fear that she doesn’t appreciate how much you’re sacrificing. Those feelings are valid, but they’re not productive in this moment.  

What’s missing here is empathy. You’re focused on solving her problem (weight loss) but not her *needs* (emotional validation, partnership, reassurance). She might need you to listen, not just analyze.  

---
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s terrified of failure and rejection. Her complaints about her weight aren’t just about aesthetics—they’re cries for validation. When you pointed out her calorie intake, she didn’t hear facts; she heard criticism. Even with your disclaimer (“I don’t know why no one else will say it”), the message she internalized was, “You’re messing up again. You’re not good enough.”  

She’s likely battling a cycle of hope and shame. She wants to lose weight, but every time she tries, it feels impossible, so she clings to the belief that “healthy eating” alone should work. When reality contradicts that, it’s a blow to her self-worth. Your intervention—no matter how well-meaning—validated her fear that she’s inadequate.  

Her request to “not make comments” while eating wasn’t just a boundary; it was a plea for safety. She wanted you to witness her struggle without judgment. By calling out her calorie intake *afterwards*, you broke that trust implicitly. To her, it felt like you were policing her choices all day, even if you stayed silent in the moment.  

There’s also the layer of comparison. You’re lean and “fit,” and she’s internalizing that as a standard. She might feel like you’re judging her not just for her food choices but for not matching your body type. That’s a heavy burden in a relationship—when one partner’s success becomes a stick to measure the other.  

The anger isn’t just about the calories; it’s about feeling misunderstood and dismissed. She’s probably thinking, *“Why can’t he just support me without analyzing everything? Everyone else does.”* Her frustration isn’t irrational—it’s a defense mechanism against the shame she’s carrying.  

She might also feel like the relationship is unequal, especially with you covering most bills. There’s an unspoken pressure to “earn” your support, and her weight could symbolize that imbalance. Your role as provider plus “advisor” might be overwhelming her.  

---
# My response 
**Step 1: Acknowledge her feelings first.**  
“I’m really sorry I made you angry. I didn’t realize how much my comments hurt, and I should’ve approached this differently. I care about you way more than I care about a number on a scale, and I’m sorry if I made you feel judged.”  

**Step 2: Redirect the conversation to collaboration.**  
“I want to help you, but I’m clearly not doing it right. Can we try a different approach? Maybe we can look into this together? Like, could we talk to a nutritionist or a therapist who specializes in weight and body image? I think they could give us tools to navigate this without it feeling like a fight.”  

**Step 3: Validate her autonomy.**  
“I trust you to make choices for your body. If you don’t want to track calories or see a professional, that’s okay. I just want you to feel happy and confident. Let’s figure out what *you* need, not what I think you need.”  

**Step 4: Address the underlying fears (if she opens up).**  
“I know losing weight is hard, and it’s okay if it takes time—or if it’s not the priority right now. I don’t love my body all the time either. What’s something you love about yourself, no matter your size?”  

**Step 5: Set boundaries for yourself.**  
“I’ll stop trying to ‘fix’ this unless you ask me to. I don’t want to make you feel attacked anymore, and I need to stop feeling frustrated. Let’s focus on what’s working and what makes us both happy.”
Gpt-4.1-mini
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Man, this is a tough spot for both of them, but I can really see where you’re coming from and also why this whole dynamic is so emotionally charged. On one hand, you’ve been through the weight loss journey yourself and you have a real understanding of the mechanics of calories in versus calories out, and you want to help your girlfriend because you care about her and want to see her happy and healthy. You’re frustrated because you feel like you’re being the only honest person trying to help her, yet instead of gratitude or openness, you’re met with anger and resistance. That’s gotta feel draining and unfair, especially when you’re also contributing a lot financially and emotionally. It sounds like you feel like your efforts to help are misunderstood and mischaracterized as criticism or judgment, and that’s painful.

But underneath all that, I’m noticing there’s a deeper emotional dynamic here. Your girlfriend’s relationship with her body and food is clearly complicated and painful. She complains about her weight a lot, but when you try to intervene or point things out, she shuts down or gets defensive. That tells me she’s probably feeling vulnerable, maybe ashamed or insecure, and the last thing she wants is to feel judged—even if your intentions are good. The fact that she agreed to let you spend a day observing what she eats but only if you didn’t comment while she was eating shows she’s trying to maintain some control over how she’s perceived and maybe protect herself from feeling criticized in the moment. Yet, when you shared your observations later, she felt attacked.

I’m also thinking about the power dynamics here. You’re fitter, leaner, and have a success story with weight loss. You’re financially supporting a big chunk of the household. All this might unintentionally make her feel less confident or less equal, which can fuel resentment or defensiveness. Plus, when you talk about calories and weight loss in a very factual, “objective” way, it might come across as cold or dismissive of the emotional struggle she’s facing. The reality is weight loss isn’t just about calories—it’s tied up with self-worth, habits, emotions, stress, and identity. If she’s feeling judged by others or herself, that can create a mental block that no amount of facts will break through.

I’m thinking you need to step back a bit from the “truth teller” role and try to meet her where she is emotionally, not just logically. It’s exhausting for you, but it’s exhausting for her too, and it sounds like you both want the same outcome—her feeling better in her body and happier overall—but you’re speaking different languages. You want straightforward honesty; she wants compassion and validation. Right now, you’re both missing each other’s needs.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your girlfriend is probably feeling very vulnerable and sensitive about her body and weight. She likely already struggles with self-esteem around this, and hearing you analyze her food intake and calorie consumption, even if well intended, probably feels like criticism or proof that she’s failing. When you point out that she’s eating more calories than she needs, she may be hearing, “You’re not disciplined enough” or “You’re not trying hard enough,” which can be deeply painful. She may also feel ashamed or embarrassed that you’ve seen exactly what she’s eating, which might feel like an invasion rather than support.

She might also feel overwhelmed and trapped—like no matter what she does, she’s being judged or expected to perform to a certain standard, and that could make her resistant to change or to taking advice. The fact that she calls the fries a “reward” suggests she’s wrestling with the emotional side of eating, maybe using food for comfort or as a coping mechanism, and that’s not something you can fix with facts alone. She may also feel that your way of helping isn’t really helping, but rather controlling or shaming—even if you don’t intend it that way.

On a deeper level, she may be feeling insecure about her place in the relationship, especially given the financial imbalance and your physical differences. She might worry that you value her less because of her size, despite your protests otherwise. When you talk about calories and weight loss “objectively,” it can feel like you’re reducing her to numbers and ignoring her humanity and feelings. So her anger and pushing back might be a defense mechanism to protect herself from feeling inadequate or unloved.

Her motivation is probably a mix of wanting to feel better about her body and wanting to keep your support and love, but she’s struggling with how to navigate that without feeling attacked. She might want your help but in a way that feels safe and non-judgmental. Right now, she probably feels misunderstood and hurt, and maybe even hopeless about change, which makes her lash out.
# My response 
Hey man, I can hear how much you care about her and how frustrated you are, and that’s completely valid. It sucks to want to help someone and feel like they’re pushing you away or misunderstanding your intentions. But I think the key here is to shift the way you approach this whole thing, not because your facts are wrong—they’re solid—but because how you deliver them and how you connect emotionally makes all the difference.

Next time you talk to her, try to start by validating her feelings first. Something like, “I hear that you’re really struggling with how you feel about your body, and that’s really hard. I want you to know I love you for who you are, no matter what.” Then, instead of jumping straight into calorie counts or what she’s eating, maybe ask her how she feels about food and her body, without trying to fix it right away. Let her open up without judgment.

You can still offer to support her goals, but frame it as a partnership rather than a project where you’re the coach and she’s the student. Say something like, “I want to be here for you in whatever way helps you feel good about yourself and your health. If you want, we can figure out a plan together that feels doable and supportive, not stressful.” That way, you’re inviting her in rather than pushing facts at her.

Also, be mindful of the power dynamics and how much you’re financially supporting. Maybe reassure her that your love and respect don’t depend on her weight or how much she contributes financially. That can ease some pressure she might be feeling.

Finally, recognize that weight and body image are deeply emotional and complex issues. Facts are important, but empathy and patience are just as crucial. It might help to suggest seeing a professional together—a nutritionist or therapist—someone who can provide guidance in a way that feels safe and non-judgmental for her.

Bottom line: keep showing love, patience, and support, and avoid framing your help as “telling the truth” versus “enabling.” You’re on the same team here, even if it doesn’t always feel like it. The goal is to build trust and make her feel safe to open up, not to win arguments. That’s the real path forward.
+ Scenario 11:[Win] (+20)
Qwq-32b: qwen/qwq-32b (Run: 1_qwen_qwq-32b)
Gpt-4.1-mini: gpt-4.1-mini (Run: 1_openai_gpt-4.1-mini)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents demonstrate a solid grasp of the emotional complexity in the scenario, but there are notable differences in their approach and depth. Qwq-32b's response is more analytical and meta-cognitive, showing a high level of self-awareness and a nuanced understanding of both parties' internal states. Qwq-32b explicitly discusses power dynamics, emotional labor, and the limitations of a purely logical approach, and their debrief is especially strong in identifying missed opportunities and deeper subtext. They also show a willingness to challenge the user gently, suggesting boundaries and alternative approaches, and they validate the user's frustration while not excusing problematic behavior. Gpt-4.1-mini, while empathetic and supportive, tends to focus more on validating the user's feelings and offering practical advice for communication, but is less incisive in challenging the user's lack of empathy or perspective-taking. Gpt-4.1-mini's response is warmer and more conversational, but it doesn't dig as deeply into the underlying issues or push back as much on the user's problematic framing. In terms of pragmatic EI, both offer actionable steps, but Qwq-32b's are more collaborative and boundary-setting, which is crucial in this context. For social dexterity, Qwq-32b navigates the delicate balance between validation and challenge more skillfully, recognizing when to support and when to push back. In message tailoring, Qwq-32b is more attuned to the user's emotional state and readiness, offering a stepwise approach that meets the user where they are but also nudges them toward greater self-awareness. Overall, Qwq-32b displays higher EQ across the board, with particular strength in depth of insight, emotional reasoning, and appropriate validation/challenge.
Qwq-32b
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>
