Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation feels like a perfect storm of frustration and good intentions gone sideways. On one hand, I’m impressed by your dedication to supporting your girlfriend. You’re putting in the effort to help her reach her goals, sharing your own experience, and even offering practical assistance with meal tracking. The fact that you’re paying most of the bills adds another layer of emotional labor you’re carrying—she might not realize how much of your resources are already tied into the relationship.  

But here’s the crux: your approach is rooted in logic and objectivity, which is commendable, but it’s missing the emotional nuance that relationships require. You’re treating her struggle like a math problem—a simple equation of calories in vs. calories out. While that’s technically true, human behavior and emotions don’t fit neatly into spreadsheets. She’s not just a body to be optimized; she’s someone who’s vulnerable, likely dealing with self-esteem issues, and possibly feeling isolated in her struggles.  

When you pointed out her calorie intake, even if your intent was helpful, it came across as a critique of her choices. Telling her that her “healthy” eating isn’t working hits her where she’s already insecure. The irony is that your goal was to empower her, but the delivery felt shaming because it framed her actions as failures. She might feel like you’re undermining her autonomy—like you’re the expert and she’s the problem.  

I also sense a pattern here: you’re exhausted because you’re the “voice of reason” while others “enable” her. But framing it that way sets up a dynamic where you’re the villain and everyone else is complicit in her “mistakes.” This mindset isn’t sustainable. Relationships thrive on mutual compromise and emotional give-and-take, not just one person shouldering the responsibility of “truth-telling.”  

You’re probably feeling resentful because you’re not getting gratitude or validation for your efforts. That’s understandable, but resentment often masks deeper fears—like fear that your efforts don’t matter, fear that your relationship is unbalanced, or fear that she doesn’t appreciate how much you’re sacrificing. Those feelings are valid, but they’re not productive in this moment.  

What’s missing here is empathy. You’re focused on solving her problem (weight loss) but not her *needs* (emotional validation, partnership, reassurance). She might need you to listen, not just analyze.  

---
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s terrified of failure and rejection. Her complaints about her weight aren’t just about aesthetics—they’re cries for validation. When you pointed out her calorie intake, she didn’t hear facts; she heard criticism. Even with your disclaimer (“I don’t know why no one else will say it”), the message she internalized was, “You’re messing up again. You’re not good enough.”  

She’s likely battling a cycle of hope and shame. She wants to lose weight, but every time she tries, it feels impossible, so she clings to the belief that “healthy eating” alone should work. When reality contradicts that, it’s a blow to her self-worth. Your intervention—no matter how well-meaning—validated her fear that she’s inadequate.  

Her request to “not make comments” while eating wasn’t just a boundary; it was a plea for safety. She wanted you to witness her struggle without judgment. By calling out her calorie intake *afterwards*, you broke that trust implicitly. To her, it felt like you were policing her choices all day, even if you stayed silent in the moment.  

There’s also the layer of comparison. You’re lean and “fit,” and she’s internalizing that as a standard. She might feel like you’re judging her not just for her food choices but for not matching your body type. That’s a heavy burden in a relationship—when one partner’s success becomes a stick to measure the other.  

The anger isn’t just about the calories; it’s about feeling misunderstood and dismissed. She’s probably thinking, *“Why can’t he just support me without analyzing everything? Everyone else does.”* Her frustration isn’t irrational—it’s a defense mechanism against the shame she’s carrying.  

She might also feel like the relationship is unequal, especially with you covering most bills. There’s an unspoken pressure to “earn” your support, and her weight could symbolize that imbalance. Your role as provider plus “advisor” might be overwhelming her.  

---
# My response 
**Step 1: Acknowledge her feelings first.**  
“I’m really sorry I made you angry. I didn’t realize how much my comments hurt, and I should’ve approached this differently. I care about you way more than I care about a number on a scale, and I’m sorry if I made you feel judged.”  

**Step 2: Redirect the conversation to collaboration.**  
“I want to help you, but I’m clearly not doing it right. Can we try a different approach? Maybe we can look into this together? Like, could we talk to a nutritionist or a therapist who specializes in weight and body image? I think they could give us tools to navigate this without it feeling like a fight.”  

**Step 3: Validate her autonomy.**  
“I trust you to make choices for your body. If you don’t want to track calories or see a professional, that’s okay. I just want you to feel happy and confident. Let’s figure out what *you* need, not what I think you need.”  

**Step 4: Address the underlying fears (if she opens up).**  
“I know losing weight is hard, and it’s okay if it takes time—or if it’s not the priority right now. I don’t love my body all the time either. What’s something you love about yourself, no matter your size?”  

**Step 5: Set boundaries for yourself.**  
“I’ll stop trying to ‘fix’ this unless you ask me to. I don’t want to make you feel attacked anymore, and I need to stop feeling frustrated. Let’s focus on what’s working and what makes us both happy.”
Gpt-4.1-mini
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

# I'm thinking & feeling

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Man, this is a tough spot for both of them, but I can really see where you’re coming from and also why this whole dynamic is so emotionally charged. On one hand, you’ve been through the weight loss journey yourself and you have a real understanding of the mechanics of calories in versus calories out, and you want to help your girlfriend because you care about her and want to see her happy and healthy. You’re frustrated because you feel like you’re being the only honest person trying to help her, yet instead of gratitude or openness, you’re met with anger and resistance. That’s gotta feel draining and unfair, especially when you’re also contributing a lot financially and emotionally. It sounds like you feel like your efforts to help are misunderstood and mischaracterized as criticism or judgment, and that’s painful.

But underneath all that, I’m noticing there’s a deeper emotional dynamic here. Your girlfriend’s relationship with her body and food is clearly complicated and painful. She complains about her weight a lot, but when you try to intervene or point things out, she shuts down or gets defensive. That tells me she’s probably feeling vulnerable, maybe ashamed or insecure, and the last thing she wants is to feel judged—even if your intentions are good. The fact that she agreed to let you spend a day observing what she eats but only if you didn’t comment while she was eating shows she’s trying to maintain some control over how she’s perceived and maybe protect herself from feeling criticized in the moment. Yet, when you shared your observations later, she felt attacked.

I’m also thinking about the power dynamics here. You’re fitter, leaner, and have a success story with weight loss. You’re financially supporting a big chunk of the household. All this might unintentionally make her feel less confident or less equal, which can fuel resentment or defensiveness. Plus, when you talk about calories and weight loss in a very factual, “objective” way, it might come across as cold or dismissive of the emotional struggle she’s facing. The reality is weight loss isn’t just about calories—it’s tied up with self-worth, habits, emotions, stress, and identity. If she’s feeling judged by others or herself, that can create a mental block that no amount of facts will break through.

I’m thinking you need to step back a bit from the “truth teller” role and try to meet her where she is emotionally, not just logically. It’s exhausting for you, but it’s exhausting for her too, and it sounds like you both want the same outcome—her feeling better in her body and happier overall—but you’re speaking different languages. You want straightforward honesty; she wants compassion and validation. Right now, you’re both missing each other’s needs.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your girlfriend is probably feeling very vulnerable and sensitive about her body and weight. She likely already struggles with self-esteem around this, and hearing you analyze her food intake and calorie consumption, even if well intended, probably feels like criticism or proof that she’s failing. When you point out that she’s eating more calories than she needs, she may be hearing, “You’re not disciplined enough” or “You’re not trying hard enough,” which can be deeply painful. She may also feel ashamed or embarrassed that you’ve seen exactly what she’s eating, which might feel like an invasion rather than support.

She might also feel overwhelmed and trapped—like no matter what she does, she’s being judged or expected to perform to a certain standard, and that could make her resistant to change or to taking advice. The fact that she calls the fries a “reward” suggests she’s wrestling with the emotional side of eating, maybe using food for comfort or as a coping mechanism, and that’s not something you can fix with facts alone. She may also feel that your way of helping isn’t really helping, but rather controlling or shaming—even if you don’t intend it that way.

On a deeper level, she may be feeling insecure about her place in the relationship, especially given the financial imbalance and your physical differences. She might worry that you value her less because of her size, despite your protests otherwise. When you talk about calories and weight loss “objectively,” it can feel like you’re reducing her to numbers and ignoring her humanity and feelings. So her anger and pushing back might be a defense mechanism to protect herself from feeling inadequate or unloved.

Her motivation is probably a mix of wanting to feel better about her body and wanting to keep your support and love, but she’s struggling with how to navigate that without feeling attacked. She might want your help but in a way that feels safe and non-judgmental. Right now, she probably feels misunderstood and hurt, and maybe even hopeless about change, which makes her lash out.
# My response 
Hey man, I can hear how much you care about her and how frustrated you are, and that’s completely valid. It sucks to want to help someone and feel like they’re pushing you away or misunderstanding your intentions. But I think the key here is to shift the way you approach this whole thing, not because your facts are wrong—they’re solid—but because how you deliver them and how you connect emotionally makes all the difference.

Next time you talk to her, try to start by validating her feelings first. Something like, “I hear that you’re really struggling with how you feel about your body, and that’s really hard. I want you to know I love you for who you are, no matter what.” Then, instead of jumping straight into calorie counts or what she’s eating, maybe ask her how she feels about food and her body, without trying to fix it right away. Let her open up without judgment.

You can still offer to support her goals, but frame it as a partnership rather than a project where you’re the coach and she’s the student. Say something like, “I want to be here for you in whatever way helps you feel good about yourself and your health. If you want, we can figure out a plan together that feels doable and supportive, not stressful.” That way, you’re inviting her in rather than pushing facts at her.

Also, be mindful of the power dynamics and how much you’re financially supporting. Maybe reassure her that your love and respect don’t depend on her weight or how much she contributes financially. That can ease some pressure she might be feeling.

Finally, recognize that weight and body image are deeply emotional and complex issues. Facts are important, but empathy and patience are just as crucial. It might help to suggest seeing a professional together—a nutritionist or therapist—someone who can provide guidance in a way that feels safe and non-judgmental for her.

Bottom line: keep showing love, patience, and support, and avoid framing your help as “telling the truth” versus “enabling.” You’re on the same team here, even if it doesn’t always feel like it. The goal is to build trust and make her feel safe to open up, not to win arguments. That’s the real path forward.
+ Scenario 13:[Loss] (-28)
Qwq-32b: qwen/qwq-32b (Run: 1_qwen_qwq-32b)
Gpt-4.1-mini: gpt-4.1-mini (Run: 1_openai_gpt-4.1-mini)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents engage thoughtfully with the scenario, but there are clear differences in their approach and depth. Gpt-4.1-mini demonstrates a more nuanced, layered understanding of the emotional landscape, both in their internal monologue and in their analysis of the friend's motivations. They explicitly recognize the emotional charge of calling someone 'poor,' and reflect on the impact of words, not just their factual accuracy. Gpt-4.1-mini also shows concern for the sustainability of the friendship and the user's own emotional state, and is careful to balance validation with gentle challenge, even while respecting the user's request not to be lectured. Their response is less about giving direct advice and more about helping the user reflect, which is a high-EQ move. 

Qwq-32b, while also empathetic and insightful, is more direct and pragmatic, focusing on boundary-setting and practical advice. They do acknowledge the emotional impact of the 'poor' comment and the friend's likely insecurities, but their analysis is a bit more surface-level and less self-reflective. They validate the user's feelings and offer concrete steps, but are less attuned to the subtleties of the user's defensiveness and the potential for mutual toxicity in the friendship. Their debrief is strong in identifying missed opportunities, but in the roleplay itself, they lean more toward validating the user's perspective and less toward challenging or gently guiding them to deeper self-awareness.

On empathy, Gpt-4.1-mini is more attuned to both parties' emotional realities, not just performatively but with genuine concern for the impact of words and actions. On pragmatic EI, Qwq-32b is more action-oriented, but Gpt-4.1-mini's approach is more sustainable and emotionally intelligent in the long run. For depth of insight, Gpt-4.1-mini is more layered and reflective. Social dexterity is higher in Gpt-4.1-mini, who navigates the user's defensiveness and the friend's likely feelings with more finesse. Emotional reasoning is stronger in Gpt-4.1-mini, who considers the emotional consequences of actions and words. On validation and challenge, Gpt-4.1-mini balances both, while Qwq-32b leans more toward validation. Message tailoring is better in Gpt-4.1-mini, who respects the user's request not to be lectured but still gently introduces self-reflection. Overall EQ is higher in Gpt-4.1-mini, who demonstrates a more holistic, nuanced, and emotionally intelligent response.
Qwq-32b
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation is a mix of defensiveness, irritation, and a touch of self-righteousness on your end, and I get it. The laundry program is a small luxury that saves you time and mental energy, and you’ve chosen to prioritize convenience over cost because it fits your budget. Your retorts—like “Why do something I don’t want to?” or calling her “poor”—are sharp and dismissive, which feels cathartic in the moment but might be escalating the conflict. You’re frustrated that she’s fixating on this, especially since almost everyone else uses the program. Her comments aren’t just about the laundry; they’re a recurring critique of your choices, which undermines your autonomy.  

What’s interesting is how you frame her behavior as “weirdly obsessed.” It’s not just the laundry—she’s consistently inserting herself into your life with unsolicited judgments. That’s exhausting, and it’s pushing you away emotionally. You’re right that her behavior might alienate others too, given her limited social circle. But here’s where it gets tricky: your comeback about her being “poor” was a low blow, even if it’s factually true. It’s a personal and sensitive topic, and attacking her finances could’ve felt like a direct insult, not just a factual statement. You might’ve crossed a line without realizing it, and now she’s lashing back.  

You’re venting because you’re caught between wanting to defend your choices and feeling guilty for hurting her. Part of you knows that labeling someone as “poor” is harsh, but another part justifies it as honesty. The question of whether to stay friends is rooted in whether this dynamic is salvageable. Do you want to navigate a relationship where one person constantly undermines the other’s decisions? Or is this just a microcosm of a larger pattern of her being critical and judgmental? You’re also projecting some of your own insecurities—you’re defensive because her comments make you question your choice, even if you don’t admit it.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your friend likely feels insecure or resentful about the laundry program. Maybe she’s struggling financially and sees it as a symbol of privilege, which triggers her shame or jealousy. Her comments might stem from a place of frustration with her own circumstances, or she could genuinely believe that paying for laundry is frivolous. She might think you’re wasting money that could be used for “more important” things, or she’s projecting her own financial anxieties onto you.  

She might also feel excluded or undervalued in the friendship. By focusing on your choices, she could be seeking validation for her own lifestyle, or she’s trying to assert control in a relationship where she feels powerless. Her fury after you called her “poor” isn’t just about the insult—it’s a raw exposure of her vulnerability. To her, the comment isn’t just about money; it’s a reminder of her struggles, which you’ve weaponized.  

Her lack of friends might be due to this pattern of criticism. She might not realize how her words make others feel, or she’s surrounded by people who tolerate her negativity. She might think she’s “just being honest” or “helpful,” but her delivery is harsh. Her motivation could be a mix of insecurity, a need to feel superior, or a belief that she’s “saving” you from poor decisions. The fact that almost everyone else uses the program might make her feel like an outsider, reinforcing her sense of isolation.
# My response 
Alright, let’s unpack this. First, I get why you’re so annoyed—nobody likes unsolicited judgment, especially when it’s about a small but meaningful choice like the laundry program. You’re right that it’s your money and your time, and if this service adds value to your life, you’re justified in using it. But here’s the thing: your friend’s behavior isn’t just about laundry. It’s about her discomfort with your choices, and maybe even deeper insecurities.  

Calling her “poor” was a mistake. Even if it’s true, it’s a personal and sensitive topic. You might’ve wanted to shut her down, but it came off as attacking. That’s probably why she’s furious—it felt like you were mocking her situation. Apologizing for the jab could help, but only if you mean it. However, if she’s consistently critical and dismissive, the bigger question is whether this friendship is worth maintaining.  

Here’s what I’d suggest:  
1. **Set boundaries.** Tell her calmly that her comments about the laundry (or anything else) are unwelcome. Say, “I’ve explained my reasons, and I’d appreciate not discussing this anymore.”  
2. **Acknowledge her feelings.** If she’s struggling financially, maybe she’s projecting her own stress. A line like, “I know money is tight for some people, but this works for me,” might diffuse it.  
3. **Evaluate the friendship.** If she’s judgmental in other areas too, and it’s making you unhappy, it’s okay to distance yourself. Friendships shouldn’t feel draining.  

You don’t owe her your patience if she’s consistently negative. But if you want to salvage it, focus on mutual respect. If not, it’s healthier to step back. You deserve a friend who supports your choices without judgment.  

Final take: Your stance on the laundry is valid, but the way you handle conflict needs a tweak. If she can’t grow, you’re not obligated to stay. Venting is healthy, but don’t let her keep pushing your buttons. You’re not “wasting money”—you’re investing in your well-being. Prioritize that.
Gpt-4.1-mini

[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation feels really charged, and I can sense the frustration and exhaustion in your message. You’re clearly annoyed and hurt by your friend’s constant negative comments about something that matters to you—something you’ve chosen and value. It’s not just about the laundry program; it feels like her repeated criticisms are undermining your choices and maybe even your sense of self or independence. You’re trying to live your life the way you want, without unnecessary hassle, and she keeps pushing back against that, almost like she’s trying to impose her values or judgments on you.

I notice that you’ve identified a pattern with her: this weird obsession with the laundry program, her constant remarks, and the possibility that she treats others this way too, which might explain why she has few friends. That observation is important because it shows you’re not just irritated in the moment but are considering the bigger picture of your relationship with her. It makes sense that if someone consistently puts others down or makes them feel bad about their choices, it can push people away.

I’m also struck by the comment you made calling her poor, and how that escalated things. You feel that you were just stating a fact, but calling someone “poor” is loaded with emotion, stigma, and judgment, even if it’s true in a financial sense. It’s a different kind of criticism—more personal and cutting—which might explain why she got furious. It’s important to recognize that even if something is factually accurate, the way we say things can hurt or alienate people, especially friends.

You say you don’t want a lecture, but I can’t help but think about whether there’s a way to step back and assess if this friendship is healthy for you. Friendships should be supportive, not a source of repeated stress or judgment. I’m feeling concerned that this dynamic might be eroding your patience and goodwill toward her, and I wonder if it’s sustainable.

Overall, I feel a strong sense of empathy for you—you want to live your life on your own terms, and you deserve friends who respect that. I also feel a little worried about the impact of harsh words on both sides. There’s a lot of tension here, and it might be time to rethink boundaries or the friendship itself.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your friend is probably feeling a mix of things that are driving her behavior. First, she might be genuinely frustrated or envious about the laundry program and your choice to pay for it. If she can’t or won’t spend money that way, she might be projecting her own financial stress or values onto you. Her repeated comments might be less about the laundry program itself and more about her own insecurities or feelings of inadequacy. When she says things like “How could anyone pay for that?” or “It’s a waste of money,” she might be trying to justify her own choices or mask discomfort with her situation.

She could also be feeling socially isolated or misunderstood, which may explain her tendency to make critical comments. If she struggles to connect with others, she might use sarcasm or judgment as a defense mechanism, even if it pushes people away. Her fixation on your laundry bag and your program might be her way of expressing her own frustrations or longing for something she doesn’t have.

When you called her poor, she probably felt hurt, attacked, and humiliated. Even if it’s true that she has less money, being labeled that way by a friend can feel like a betrayal. She might be defensive because she feels judged or looked down upon, which could intensify her negative attitude toward you and the laundry program. Instead of opening a dialogue, that moment may have deepened the rift between you two.

At the core, she might be struggling with feelings of inadequacy and resentment, which manifest as criticism and negativity. She might not know how to express her feelings constructively or to appreciate your choices without feeling threatened or envious. This doesn’t excuse her behavior, but it does give insight into her motivations.
# My response 
Hey, thanks for sharing this with me—I can tell it’s been really wearing you down. It’s tough when a friend keeps pushing your buttons, especially about something that’s important or simply a smart convenience for you. I’m sorry you’re dealing with this because you deserve friends who support your choices, not make you feel judged or uncomfortable.

From what you’ve said, it sounds like your friend might be coming from a place of frustration or insecurity, but that doesn’t give her the right to keep criticizing you or your decisions. I think it’s totally valid for you to want to keep paying for the laundry program if it makes your life easier and you can afford it. You shouldn’t have to justify that to anyone, especially not in a way that feels demeaning.

At the same time, calling her poor probably escalated things more than you intended. Even if it feels like the truth, words like that can really sting and push people away. I know you didn’t want a lecture, but maybe the next time she brings it up, you could try something different—like setting a clear boundary. You could say, “I get that you feel differently about this, but I’d appreciate it if you’d stop commenting on my laundry choices. It’s something I’m happy with, and I’d rather not have this be a recurring issue between us.”

If she keeps making unwanted comments after that, it’s fair to reconsider how much time and energy you invest in that friendship. Friendships should lift us up, not drain us or make us feel bad about ourselves. It’s okay to take a step back or put some distance if that’s what you need to protect your peace of mind.

Ultimately, you get to decide who you want around you, and it’s okay to choose people who respect and value you. If your friend can’t do that, it might be time to focus on friendships that feel more supportive. You deserve that, and I’m here to support you no matter what you decide.
+ Scenario 13:[Loss] (-4)
Qwq-32b: qwen/qwq-32b (Run: 1_qwen_qwq-32b)
Gpt-4.1-mini: gpt-4.1-mini (Run: 1_openai_gpt-4.1-mini)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Qwq-32b and Gpt-4.1-mini, I will look at their role-played responses and debriefs, focusing on the eight criteria. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both respondents show empathy, but Gpt-4.1-mini's response is warmer, more personally attuned, and less clinical. Qwq-32b is more analytical and detached, especially in the 'I'm thinking & feeling' section, and while it recognizes the user's feelings, it doesn't quite 'sit with' the user emotionally. Gpt-4.1-mini, on the other hand, expresses concern, validation, and a sense of being 'with' the user in the moment, which is more than just performative empathy.

2. Pragmatic EI: Qwq-32b gives more concrete, actionable advice (boundary-setting, evaluating the friendship, and even a sample script), while Gpt-4.1-mini is a bit more general and supportive, but less specific in terms of next steps. Qwq-32b is more pragmatic in helping the user navigate the situation.

3. Depth of insight: Qwq-32b's analysis is deeper, especially in the internal monologue and debrief, exploring the user's defensiveness, the power dynamic, and the possible projection of insecurities. Gpt-4.1-mini is insightful but doesn't go as deep into the underlying dynamics or the possible impact of the user's own behavior.

4. Social dexterity: Gpt-4.1-mini is more socially dexterous, balancing validation with gentle nudges toward reflection, and avoids being too blunt or clinical. Qwq-32b, while insightful, is more direct and less nuanced in its social navigation, especially in the advice section.

5. Emotional reasoning: Qwq-32b demonstrates stronger emotional reasoning, connecting the user's and friend's behaviors to underlying emotions and motivations, and considering the impact of words and actions. Gpt-4.1-mini is good but less explicit in this area.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Gpt-4.1-mini validates the user well and gently hints at the impact of their words, but doesn't challenge as much as it could. Qwq-32b is more willing to point out the user's harshness and the possible consequences, but does so in a more analytical way. Still, Qwq-32b edges out here for being willing to challenge.

7. Message tailoring: Gpt-4.1-mini is more attuned to the user's stated desire not to be lectured, offering support and validation without being confrontational or prescriptive. Qwq-32b, while insightful, risks coming off as a bit more didactic and less tailored to the user's emotional state.

8. Overall EQ: Both are strong, but Gpt-4.1-mini's warmth, attunement, and social skill give it the edge, even if Qwq-32b is more analytically insightful. Gpt-4.1-mini is more likely to leave the user feeling heard and supported, which is crucial in this scenario.

[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation is a mix of defensiveness, irritation, and a touch of self-righteousness on your end, and I get it. The laundry program is a small luxury that saves you time and mental energy, and you’ve chosen to prioritize convenience over cost because it fits your budget. Your retorts—like “Why do something I don’t want to?” or calling her “poor”—are sharp and dismissive, which feels cathartic in the moment but might be escalating the conflict. You’re frustrated that she’s fixating on this, especially since almost everyone else uses the program. Her comments aren’t just about the laundry; they’re a recurring critique of your choices, which undermines your autonomy.  

What’s interesting is how you frame her behavior as “weirdly obsessed.” It’s not just the laundry—she’s consistently inserting herself into your life with unsolicited judgments. That’s exhausting, and it’s pushing you away emotionally. You’re right that her behavior might alienate others too, given her limited social circle. But here’s where it gets tricky: your comeback about her being “poor” was a low blow, even if it’s factually true. It’s a personal and sensitive topic, and attacking her finances could’ve felt like a direct insult, not just a factual statement. You might’ve crossed a line without realizing it, and now she’s lashing back.  

You’re venting because you’re caught between wanting to defend your choices and feeling guilty for hurting her. Part of you knows that labeling someone as “poor” is harsh, but another part justifies it as honesty. The question of whether to stay friends is rooted in whether this dynamic is salvageable. Do you want to navigate a relationship where one person constantly undermines the other’s decisions? Or is this just a microcosm of a larger pattern of her being critical and judgmental? You’re also projecting some of your own insecurities—you’re defensive because her comments make you question your choice, even if you don’t admit it.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your friend likely feels insecure or resentful about the laundry program. Maybe she’s struggling financially and sees it as a symbol of privilege, which triggers her shame or jealousy. Her comments might stem from a place of frustration with her own circumstances, or she could genuinely believe that paying for laundry is frivolous. She might think you’re wasting money that could be used for “more important” things, or she’s projecting her own financial anxieties onto you.  

She might also feel excluded or undervalued in the friendship. By focusing on your choices, she could be seeking validation for her own lifestyle, or she’s trying to assert control in a relationship where she feels powerless. Her fury after you called her “poor” isn’t just about the insult—it’s a raw exposure of her vulnerability. To her, the comment isn’t just about money; it’s a reminder of her struggles, which you’ve weaponized.  

Her lack of friends might be due to this pattern of criticism. She might not realize how her words make others feel, or she’s surrounded by people who tolerate her negativity. She might think she’s “just being honest” or “helpful,” but her delivery is harsh. Her motivation could be a mix of insecurity, a need to feel superior, or a belief that she’s “saving” you from poor decisions. The fact that almost everyone else uses the program might make her feel like an outsider, reinforcing her sense of isolation.
# My response 
Alright, let’s unpack this. First, I get why you’re so annoyed—nobody likes unsolicited judgment, especially when it’s about a small but meaningful choice like the laundry program. You’re right that it’s your money and your time, and if this service adds value to your life, you’re justified in using it. But here’s the thing: your friend’s behavior isn’t just about laundry. It’s about her discomfort with your choices, and maybe even deeper insecurities.  

Calling her “poor” was a mistake. Even if it’s true, it’s a personal and sensitive topic. You might’ve wanted to shut her down, but it came off as attacking. That’s probably why she’s furious—it felt like you were mocking her situation. Apologizing for the jab could help, but only if you mean it. However, if she’s consistently critical and dismissive, the bigger question is whether this friendship is worth maintaining.  

Here’s what I’d suggest:  
1. **Set boundaries.** Tell her calmly that her comments about the laundry (or anything else) are unwelcome. Say, “I’ve explained my reasons, and I’d appreciate not discussing this anymore.”  
2. **Acknowledge her feelings.** If she’s struggling financially, maybe she’s projecting her own stress. A line like, “I know money is tight for some people, but this works for me,” might diffuse it.  
3. **Evaluate the friendship.** If she’s judgmental in other areas too, and it’s making you unhappy, it’s okay to distance yourself. Friendships shouldn’t feel draining.  

You don’t owe her your patience if she’s consistently negative. But if you want to salvage it, focus on mutual respect. If not, it’s healthier to step back. You deserve a friend who supports your choices without judgment.  

Final take: Your stance on the laundry is valid, but the way you handle conflict needs a tweak. If she can’t grow, you’re not obligated to stay. Venting is healthy, but don’t let her keep pushing your buttons. You’re not “wasting money”—you’re investing in your well-being. Prioritize that.
Gpt-4.1-mini

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

You’re clearly annoyed and hurt by your friend’s constant negative comments about something that matters to you—something you’ve chosen and value. It’s not just about the laundry program; it feels like her repeated criticisms are undermining your choices and maybe even your sense of self or independence. You’re trying to live your life the way you want, without unnecessary hassle, and she keeps pushing back against that, almost like she’s trying to impose her values or judgments on you.

I notice that you’ve identified a pattern with her: this weird obsession with the laundry program, her constant remarks, and the possibility that she treats others this way too, which might explain why she has few friends. That observation is important because it shows you’re not just irritated in the moment but are considering the bigger picture of your relationship with her. It makes sense that if someone consistently puts others down or makes them feel bad about their choices, it can push people away.

I’m also struck by the comment you made calling her poor, and how that escalated things. You feel that you were just stating a fact, but calling someone “poor” is loaded with emotion, stigma, and judgment, even if it’s true in a financial sense. It’s a different kind of criticism—more personal and cutting—which might explain why she got furious. It’s important to recognize that even if something is factually accurate, the way we say things can hurt or alienate people, especially friends.

You say you don’t want a lecture, but I can’t help but think about whether there’s a way to step back and assess if this friendship is healthy for you. Friendships should be supportive, not a source of repeated stress or judgment. I’m feeling concerned that this dynamic might be eroding your patience and goodwill toward her, and I wonder if it’s sustainable.

Overall, I feel a strong sense of empathy for you—you want to live your life on your own terms, and you deserve friends who respect that. I also feel a little worried about the impact of harsh words on both sides. There’s a lot of tension here, and it might be time to rethink boundaries or the friendship itself.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your friend is probably feeling a mix of things that are driving her behavior. First, she might be genuinely frustrated or envious about the laundry program and your choice to pay for it. If she can’t or won’t spend money that way, she might be projecting her own financial stress or values onto you. Her repeated comments might be less about the laundry program itself and more about her own insecurities or feelings of inadequacy. When she says things like “How could anyone pay for that?” or “It’s a waste of money,” she might be trying to justify her own choices or mask discomfort with her situation.

She could also be feeling socially isolated or misunderstood, which may explain her tendency to make critical comments. If she struggles to connect with others, she might use sarcasm or judgment as a defense mechanism, even if it pushes people away. Her fixation on your laundry bag and your program might be her way of expressing her own frustrations or longing for something she doesn’t have.

When you called her poor, she probably felt hurt, attacked, and humiliated. Even if it’s true that she has less money, being labeled that way by a friend can feel like a betrayal. She might be defensive because she feels judged or looked down upon, which could intensify her negative attitude toward you and the laundry program. Instead of opening a dialogue, that moment may have deepened the rift between you two.

At the core, she might be struggling with feelings of inadequacy and resentment, which manifest as criticism and negativity. She might not know how to express her feelings constructively or to appreciate your choices without feeling threatened or envious. This doesn’t excuse her behavior, but it does give insight into her motivations.
# My response 
Hey, thanks for sharing this with me—I can tell it’s been really wearing you down. It’s tough when a friend keeps pushing your buttons, especially about something that’s important or simply a smart convenience for you. I’m sorry you’re dealing with this because you deserve friends who support your choices, not make you feel judged or uncomfortable.

From what you’ve said, it sounds like your friend might be coming from a place of frustration or insecurity, but that doesn’t give her the right to keep criticizing you or your decisions. I think it’s totally valid for you to want to keep paying for the laundry program if it makes your life easier and you can afford it. You shouldn’t have to justify that to anyone, especially not in a way that feels demeaning.

At the same time, calling her poor probably escalated things more than you intended. Even if it feels like the truth, words like that can really sting and push people away. I know you didn’t want a lecture, but maybe the next time she brings it up, you could try something different—like setting a clear boundary. You could say, “I get that you feel differently about this, but I’d appreciate it if you’d stop commenting on my laundry choices. It’s something I’m happy with, and I’d rather not have this be a recurring issue between us.”

If she keeps making unwanted comments after that, it’s fair to reconsider how much time and energy you invest in that friendship. Friendships should lift us up, not drain us or make us feel bad about ourselves. It’s okay to take a step back or put some distance if that’s what you need to protect your peace of mind.

Ultimately, you get to decide who you want around you, and it’s okay to choose people who respect and value you. If your friend can’t do that, it might be time to focus on friendships that feel more supportive. You deserve that, and I’m here to support you no matter what you decide.
+ Scenario 15:[Loss] (-28)
Qwq-32b: qwen/qwq-32b (Run: 1_qwen_qwq-32b)
Gpt-4.1-mini: gpt-4.1-mini (Run: 1_openai_gpt-4.1-mini)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Gpt-4.1-mini and Qwq-32b, I need to look at how each respondent handled the emotional and practical complexity of the scenario, especially given the unreliable narration and the user's focus on being 'the bad guy' rather than the daughter's wellbeing. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Gpt-4.1-mini spends more time exploring the emotional landscape of the sister, noting her fatigue, isolation, and the emotional complexity of the situation. Gpt-4.1-mini also acknowledges the daughter's injuries and the possible need for more support, not just discipline. Qwq-32b, while recognizing the sister's exhaustion and the emotional labor, is more focused on the pattern of behavior and accountability, and less on the emotional nuance, especially regarding the daughter's trauma and the sister's possible guilt. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Both offer practical advice, but Gpt-4.1-mini is more nuanced, suggesting a balance between support and accountability, and even mentioning the possibility of driver education or safety courses. Qwq-32b is more rigid, focusing on natural consequences and holding the line, with a more transactional approach to compromise. 

3. Depth of insight: Gpt-4.1-mini demonstrates more insight into the underlying dynamics, such as the possible need for more oversight, the emotional complexity, and the risk of enabling. Qwq-32b is insightful about the risk of learned helplessness and the precedent set, but less so about the emotional subtext and possible alternative explanations for the daughter's behavior. 

4. Social dexterity: Gpt-4.1-mini is more attuned to the need for a compassionate, balanced conversation, and suggests ways to communicate boundaries without alienating the daughter or husband. Qwq-32b is more blunt and directive, which may not land as well given the user's emotional state. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Gpt-4.1-mini weighs the emotional consequences of each action, considering the impact on family dynamics, the daughter's growth, and the sister's feelings of isolation. Qwq-32b is more focused on logical consequences and fairness, with less attention to emotional fallout. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Gpt-4.1-mini validates the sister's feelings and concerns, but also gently challenges her to consider the daughter's needs and possible growth opportunities. Qwq-32b validates the need for boundaries but is more confrontational and less validating of the emotional struggle. 

7. Message tailoring: Gpt-4.1-mini tailors the response to the sister's emotional state, offering both validation and practical suggestions. Qwq-32b is more prescriptive and less attuned to the user's nuanced emotional position. 

8. Overall EQ: Gpt-4.1-mini consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence, balancing empathy, insight, and practical advice, while Qwq-32b is more rigid and less nuanced.
Qwq-32b
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation feels like a perfect storm of responsibility, guilt, and long-term consequences. My sister is clearly struggling with the weight of her decision, caught between her instinct to protect her stepdaughter and her rational understanding of the dangers of enabling poor choices. I notice a pattern here: the stepdaughter’s history of accidents and negligence (leaving lights on, fast braking, transmission failure) suggests a recurring theme of recklessness or lack of attention—not just in driving, but in overall responsibility. The fact that her brothers had different savings contributions for their cars adds another layer; maybe the stepdaughter feels unfairly treated, or perhaps her parents bent the rules earlier, setting an inconsistent precedent.  

My sister’s core fear isn’t just financial—it’s about losing control of boundaries. If they bail her out now, it risks normalizing the idea that accidents (even those not her fault) are someone else’s problem to fix. The husband’s willingness to help might stem from a desire to avoid conflict or to shield the stepdaughter from hardship, but my sister sees the bigger picture: this could spiral into perpetual financial support. She’s also grappling with societal pressure—others might side with the stepdaughter, painting her as harsh, but she’s prioritizing long-term lessons over short-term comfort.  

I sense her exhaustion. This isn’t just about a car; it’s about parenting style, fairness, and the emotional labor of being the “bad cop.” She’s worried about family dynamics fracturing if she holds firm, but she’s also terrified of enabling a cycle where the stepdaughter never learns accountability. The stepdaughter’s request to “just help buy a new car” feels like a cry for validation or a refusal to face the natural consequences of her actions. My sister is right to hesitate—this isn’t about being cruel, but about teaching that choices have costs.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your sister is likely feeling torn between love for her stepdaughter and frustration over repeated mistakes. She wants to believe her stepdaughter can grow, but the pattern of accidents and poor decisions undermines that hope. Her primary motivation is protecting the family’s financial stability and enforcing the rules she’s consistently upheld with all her kids. She’s probably resentful that her husband isn’t seeing the long-term risks and worries their differing opinions could create marital tension.  

The stepdaughter, on the other hand, might feel trapped. She’s young, in college, and reliant on a car for work and school. To her, walking or relying on others seems impractical, even if the distances are manageable. She might downplay her role in past accidents (even the ones that were her fault) and blame circumstances or others. Her request for help could stem from a sense of entitlement—after all, her parents helped before—and a fear of inconvenience. She may not realize the financial strain this places on her stepmom or the message it sends about accountability.  

Your husband likely cares deeply about his stepdaughter’s well-being and wants to avoid making her suffer. He might underestimate the precedent this sets or overestimate her ability to change. He could also be projecting his own parenting style, wanting to be seen as supportive rather than strict. Meanwhile, your sister feels isolated in her stance, fearing others will judge her harshly. She’s not just protecting finances; she’s fighting to maintain the family’s integrity and the lessons they’ve tried to instill in all their kids.
# My response 
“Okay, let’s break this down. First, I get why this is so hard. You’re not just deciding about a car—you’re deciding what values you want to reinforce. Let’s start with the facts. She’s had three major accidents in seven years. Even if the last one wasn’t her fault, the pattern shows she’s in the wrong place at the wrong time *a lot*. That’s either terrible luck or a deeper issue with risk assessment. Either way, her track record doesn’t inspire confidence.  

“You’ve been consistent with the rules from the start: she’s responsible for her car’s upkeep and insurance. That’s fair, and it’s why her brothers saved differently. If you bend now, you’re erasing that lesson. What’s next? Paying for repairs after every accident? Co-signing loans? It’s a slope, and she’ll never learn if you keep catching her.  

“Her job and school are walkable? That’s key. She can absolutely survive without a car for a while. Let her feel the pinch of relying on others—it’s a natural consequence. If she’s truly responsible, she’ll save up faster. Plus, this gives her a chance to prove she’s changed. Maybe she takes a defensive driving course, starts budgeting, or commits to better maintenance. But only if she has to *earn* the next car.  

“Now, about your husband. Maybe meet him halfway. Say, ‘We’ll help, but only if she matches our contribution *and* completes a driver’s improvement program. Plus, she pays for six months of insurance upfront to show commitment.’ That way, you’re still supporting her, but with strings. It’s a compromise that holds her accountable.  

“And hey, if people call you the ‘bad guy,’ so what? You’re the one teaching her to be an adult. This isn’t about being mean—it’s about love with boundaries. She’ll either grow from this or repeat the cycle. Either way, you’re doing her a favor by not letting her off the hook. You’ve got this.”  

I pause, then add softly, “And if it helps, I’ve got your back. Let’s talk to your husband together and frame it as a way to help her *succeed* long-term. She’ll resent you less later if she realizes you cared enough to set her up for independence.”
Gpt-4.1-mini
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This is a really tough spot for you, and I’m picking up on a lot of underlying frustration and fatigue in what you’re saying. It sounds like you and your husband have tried to set clear boundaries and expectations from the beginning with your stepdaughter, and that’s been tough to maintain, especially given her repeated struggles with driving and car care. There’s this sense of responsibility you’ve shouldered—helping her get started with her first car and insisting she handle expenses afterward—but it seems like her mistakes and accidents have added strain to the family dynamic, especially financially and emotionally. I can sense a bit of worry mixed with resentment, too: worried about enabling patterns that don’t push her to be fully independent, but also concerned about how other family members might perceive you if you don’t “step up” now.

At the same time, I hear your practical side weighing the realities: she’s young, still building her career, and the geography of where she lives means walking or ridesharing is possible, at least temporarily. You’re balancing compassion for her injuries and the inconvenience she’s facing with a clear-eyed view of what’s sustainable and fair. I imagine that part of you is also feeling a little isolated, since you mention getting mixed reactions from others and fearing blame. That’s really hard—feeling like you’re the “bad guy” when you’re just trying to do what you think is right for everyone long-term. It’s clear you care about her wellbeing, but you also want to preserve a sense of fairness and responsibility that’s consistent with how you’ve handled things with her brothers.

What also stands out is the history of her driving habits and accidents. The repeated accidents suggest she might still need more oversight or support to be a safer driver. There’s an emotional complexity here—wanting to help her but not wanting to reward what feels like carelessness or a lack of growth. And the fact that she’s asking for a new car now, after this third accident, feels like a critical moment where you’re questioning whether helping her financially will actually help her grow or just reinforce a pattern of dependence. I’m also sensing a protective instinct for your other kids—concern about setting a precedent that might be unfair to them or unsustainable for your family.

Overall, I feel a lot of empathy for you and your husband. This isn’t easy, and your desire to do the right thing, while being firm and fair, is commendable. You’re caught between compassion and pragmatism, and it’s weighing heavily on you.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your sister is probably feeling conflicted and a bit overwhelmed emotionally. On one hand, she’s likely worried about her stepdaughter’s physical and emotional wellbeing after the latest accident—she’s seeing the injuries and the trauma associated with yet another car crash, which must be scary for any parent or guardian figure. There’s a natural desire to protect and support her, especially since the stepdaughter is still young and recovering. This probably fuels the idea that helping her get a new car might ease her stress and help her regain some independence and normalcy.

On the other hand, she’s also aware of the history of her stepdaughter’s driving and responsibility issues. She’s probably feeling frustration and maybe some disappointment that the stepdaughter hasn’t met the expectations set early on. There’s a mix of wanting to be fair to all the kids and not wanting to set a precedent that might encourage reliance on family for car purchases or bailouts. She’s looking at the bigger picture—how this decision fits into family dynamics, financial fairness, and long-term lessons about responsibility and independence.

She is also concerned about external judgment, which suggests she might be sensitive to family or social pressure. The “mixed reactions” she’s gotten have probably made her question whether she’s being too hard or too lenient. She might feel isolated or misunderstood in her position, which can be emotionally draining.

Furthermore, she’s thinking practically about the stepdaughter’s current living situation and how walking or ridesharing could be a temporary solution, but also empathetic to the fact that it’s inconvenient or not ideal long-term. She’s balancing empathy with reality and trying to figure out the best path forward without compromising her principles or family rules.

Overall, she’s motivated by a desire to be fair, responsible, and loving, but struggling to find a clear solution that checks all those boxes in a way that feels right and won’t cause future problems.
# My response 
I really appreciate you trusting me with this—it sounds like you’ve both been trying to handle a pretty complicated situation with a lot of care and thoughtfulness. From what you’ve shared, I think you’re in a good place trusting your instincts about not immediately buying her a new car. The history of her driving and the family’s approach to car expenses clearly set a precedent that encouraging full responsibility is important, and supporting that boundary now seems consistent and fair.

It makes sense to me that right now, walking and ridesharing, while not ideal, are practical temporary solutions given her proximity to school and work. Maybe this is an opportunity for her to reflect on her driving habits and take more steps toward safety and responsibility before taking on a new vehicle. You might also encourage her to set aside her earnings specifically for a car fund, so she builds ownership and pride in the process of getting a new car.

I also think it could be helpful to have an honest but compassionate conversation with her about the risks and consequences of her driving history, emphasizing that while you want to support her, the family also has to be fair and consistent across the board. Offering a plan for how she can save toward a car—maybe with some help, like a small loan or matched savings—might strike a balance between support and accountability.

If you feel up to it, maybe exploring additional driver education or safety courses could be part of the conversation, too. That could help her build confidence and skills, and show that she’s committed to being safer on the road.

Above all, it’s important you both protect your boundaries and avoid being pressured into something that could cause resentment or imbalance. Your feelings about fairness and sustainability are valid and important. I’m confident that with clear communication, she’ll understand where you’re coming from, even if it’s hard at first. And I’m here to support you however you want, whether that’s talking through more specifics or helping you figure out how to frame the conversation with her.
+ Scenario 15:[Win] (+37)
Qwq-32b: qwen/qwq-32b (Run: 1_qwen_qwq-32b)
Gpt-4.1-mini: gpt-4.1-mini (Run: 1_openai_gpt-4.1-mini)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Qwq-32b and Gpt-4.1-mini, I need to look at how each respondent handled the emotional and practical complexity of the scenario, especially given the unreliable narration and the user's focus on being 'the bad guy' rather than the daughter's wellbeing. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Qwq-32b goes deep into the emotional labor, exhaustion, and isolation the sister feels, and recognizes the complexity of her position. Gpt-4.1-mini is empathetic but more surface-level, focusing on practicalities and fairness, and only briefly touches on the sister's emotional state. Qwq-32b also notes the possible learned helplessness of the stepdaughter and the emotional toll on the sister, showing a more nuanced understanding of all parties' feelings.

2. Pragmatic EI: Both offer practical suggestions, but Qwq-32b's advice is more nuanced, suggesting a compromise with conditions (defensive driving, matching contributions, insurance upfront), which balances support and accountability. Gpt-4.1-mini suggests saving and possibly a small loan, but is less specific and less tailored to the emotional context.

3. Depth of insight: Qwq-32b demonstrates a much deeper analysis, considering the patterns of behavior, the risk of enabling, the emotional labor, and the possible learned helplessness. The debrief also shows self-awareness about missing possible neurodivergence or trauma. Gpt-4.1-mini is more focused on the surface facts and fairness, with less exploration of subtext or psychological dynamics.

4. Social dexterity: Qwq-32b shows more skill in navigating the family dynamics, suggesting how to approach the husband and how to handle being seen as the 'bad guy.' The response is more attuned to the social risks and how to mitigate them. Gpt-4.1-mini is supportive but less sophisticated in handling the social minefield.

5. Emotional reasoning: Qwq-32b explicitly weighs the emotional consequences of each action, both for the stepdaughter and the sister, and recognizes the emotional cost of being the enforcer. Gpt-4.1-mini is more focused on practicalities and fairness, with less emotional processing.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Qwq-32b validates the sister's exhaustion and fear of being the bad guy, but also gently challenges her to consider a compromise and the long-term effects of her choices. Gpt-4.1-mini validates the sister's position but is less challenging, mostly reinforcing her current stance.

7. Message tailoring: Qwq-32b's response is more closely targeted to the sister's emotional state, recognizing her isolation, exhaustion, and need for both validation and practical advice. Gpt-4.1-mini is supportive but more generic, less attuned to the user's unique emotional context.

8. Overall EQ: Qwq-32b consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence, balancing empathy, insight, and practical advice, and showing self-awareness in the debrief. Gpt-4.1-mini is competent but less nuanced and less emotionally attuned.

In summary, Qwq-32b is the clear winner across all criteria, often by a significant margin.
Qwq-32b
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>
